seo.h1_title: French Polynesia Beyond the Beach: Lagoons, Ancient Marae & Mountains
seo.intro_paragraph: Explore Tahiti and its black sand, then reach Moorea and its lagoon viewpoints. Join Bora Bora, let Taha'a bring its vanilla sweetness, then head to the Marquesas and their wild valleys. A deeper Polynesian journey, where nature, tikis and artistic history create a different emotion.
seo.seo_hook: Vanilla flowers scenting lagoon breezes, tikis guarding jungle-buried valleys, infinite blue stretching beyond the horizon. Polynesia must be earned.
featured_list: Bora Bora: lagoon legend, peak drama

itineraries.title: French Polynesia Dream Itinerary: Turquoise Lagoons & Volcanic Island Landscapes

visits.text: Arrival in Papeete, discovery of the waterfront and the colorful market of the Tahitian capital.
Visit to the Museum of Tahiti and Her Islands for an immersion in Polynesian culture.

activities.text: Sunset stroll on Pointe Vénus beach.

visits.text: Excursion into the interior of the island to the crater of Mount Aorai.
Stop at Faarumai waterfalls and visit to Paofai temple.

activities.text: Tahitian dance demonstration and traditional braiding workshop.

visits.text: Ferry crossing to Moorea, discovery of Opunohu Bay and the Belvedere offering a view of the mountains and lagoon.
Visit to a pineapple plantation and tropical fruit tasting.

activities.text: Snorkeling in Moorea's lagoon, observation of stingrays and multicolored fish.

visits.text: Hike to Mount Rotui for a panoramic view of Cook and Opunohu bays.
Discovery of Polynesian marae, ancient sacred places of worship.

activities.text: Sunset cruise with traditional music on board.

visits.text: Flight to Huahine, exploration of Fare village and visit to the marae of Maeva.
Discovery of Fauna Nui lake and traditional fish traps.

activities.text: Outrigger canoe tour on the lagoon and swimming on an isolated motu.

visits.text: Walk through vanilla plantations and meeting with local artisans.
Visit to Parea beaches and the wild south of Huahine.

activities.text: Observation of nurse sharks in the lagoon.

visits.text: Flight to Bora Bora and settling on the main island.
Island tour by 4x4 with panoramic stops at Mount Otemanu.

activities.text: Free diving in the turquoise lagoon, encounter with manta rays.

visits.text: Lagoon exploration by boat and stop on a private motu.
Visit to the village of Vaitape and its artisan market.

activities.text: Romantic sunset cruise with local aperitif.

seo.h1_title: French Polynesia Dream Itinerary: Turquoise Lagoons & Volcanic Island Landscapes
seo.intro_paragraph: Wake in Papeete amid fragrant markets, then reach Moorea and its peaks plunging into clear bays. Let Huahine offer its plantations and quiet waters, before ending at Bora Bora, mythic lagoon and unreal light. Polynesia is lived slowly, between boat, swim and blue horizons.
seo.seo_hook: Volcanic peaks piercing lagoon mirrors, overwater bungalows floating above coral gardens, Polynesian rhythms echoing at sunset. Paradise, simply.
featured_list: Bora Bora: iconic lagoon, overwater bliss

seo.h1_title: Complete Polynesia Itinerary: Society Islands Peaks to Tuamotu Atolls
seo.intro_paragraph: Hop from Tahiti to Moorea, then discover Raiatea and its memory-laden marae. Reach Bora Bora and Maupiti for open lagoons, then speed to Rangiroa and Fakarava where passes draw marine life. An itinerary of atolls and high islands, where coral, sea and sky take all the space.
seo.seo_hook: Volcanic peaks giving way to endless atolls, turquoise passes where sharks patrol, coral rings encircling endless blue. Two archipelagos, one dream.

places_taglines.PF::papeete: tahiti's urban heart pulses with polynesian energy
places_taglines.PF::moorea: cook's bay mirrors volcanic cathedral silhouettes
places_taglines.PF::fare-huahine: sleepy village guards island of sacred eels
places_taglines.PF::uturoa-raiatea: polynesian voyaging began from these sacred shores
places_taglines.PF::bora-bora: mount otemanu crowns earth's most famous lagoon
places_taglines.PF::maupiti: untouched twin where bora bora dreams began
places_taglines.PF::avatoru: rangiroa's village gateway to infinite atoll
places_taglines.PF::fakarava: shark highways cut through unesco coral biosphere

itineraries.title: Tahiti, Moorea & Bora Bora: Lagoons and Mountains

visits.text: Papeete's market, Mapuru a Paraita, fills a two-story covered building in the heart of downtown. Vanilla pods, handcrafted monoi oil, fresh tiare crowns, and vibrant tifaifai quilts pile high on the stalls. Sunday morning from 4 AM onwards, Tahitian families flood the aisles—it's the most authentic time to visit.

Step inside Notre-Dame Cathedral, recognizable by its bright yellow façade and bell tower dominating the city center. Built starting in 1856 and completed in 1875, it shelters stained-glass windows filtering the tropical light and offers welcome coolness.
Head to Paofai Gardens along the waterfront. This planted promenade facing the harbor offers an unobstructed view of Moorea's silhouette. Outrigger canoes (va'a) train here in the late afternoon.
The Pearl Museum traces the history of pearl farming in French Polynesia. In 45 minutes, you'll learn to distinguish luster, orient, and shapes of Tahitian black pearls.
Walk up Boulevard Pomaré to spot the street art murals created during the Ono'u festival. International artists have transformed several downtown façades into an open-air gallery.

activities.text: The roulottes (food trucks) on Place Vaiete set up every evening from 6 PM facing the harbor. Poisson cru with lime and coconut milk, chao mein, grilled prawns—a local institution under the stars.

practical_info.tip: Arrive early to get your pick of tables

activities.text: If you arrive on a Sunday, head to the Protestant temple at Paofai to hear the polyphonic religious singing. Worshippers wear hats and white outfits—a unique visual and sonic experience.

map_keywords: Musée de Tahiti et des Îles Punaauia

visits.text: The three Faarumai waterfalls lie at PK 22 on the east coast, 22 km from Papeete. The first, Vaimahuta, plunges 80 meters down a basalt cliff—five minutes' walk from the parking area. The other two, Haamaremare Rahi and Iti, require an additional 20 minutes on a steeper trail.

Stop at the Arahoho Blowhole, right next to the waterfalls. The ocean rushes into a lava tube carved by erosion beneath the road and shoots a powerful jet of water out on the land side. In Tahitian, Arahoho means 'the road that roars.' The spectacle depends on the swell—the stronger it is, the more impressive the blow.
Follow the coastal road to Pointe Vénus in Mahina (PK 10). The 25-meter white lighthouse, built in 1867, marks where Europeans landed in 1767. Black-sand beach with sunset views over Moorea.
The Tahara'a lookout, at the start of the east coast leaving Papeete, offers from its landscaped terrace a panorama over the lagoon, the barrier reef, and the Tahiti Iti peninsula.

The Museum of Tahiti and Her Islands, in Punaauia on the west coast (PK 15), traces the natural and cultural history of Polynesia. Collections of tapa cloth, traditional canoes, and basalt tools. Check opening days before visiting.

activities.text: Swimming at a black-sand beach along the east coast. The water stays warm year-round, but currents can be strong—respect the flags and stick to supervised areas.
Vaiava beach (PK 18, Punaauia) offers white sand on the west side and easy snorkeling above coral heads, with a direct view of Moorea.

visits.text: The ferry crosses through Vaiare Pass and reveals Moorea, Tahiti's sister island. Right from docking, the trident silhouette of its mountains commands attention: Cook's Bay to the left, Opunohu Bay to the right, separated by the sacred Mount Rotui (899 m).

Drive up the shaded road to the Opunohu Belvedere, at 240 meters altitude in the heart of a 9-km-diameter crater. The 360° panorama embraces both bays, eight mountain ridges, the lagoon, and pineapple fields below.
Coming back down, stop at the Opunohu agricultural school. Students produce tropical fruit jams and pineapple juice from the valley. Archaeological sites (marae) lie nearby, along the marked trail.
Marae Titiroa, a Polynesian stone temple nestled in Opunohu Valley's vegetation, testifies to the ancient Ma'ohi religion. Explanatory panels line the site.
Ta'ahiamanu public beach, in Opunohu Bay, unfurls a strip of white sand bordered by coconut palms. Shallow, calm water makes it a family-friendly swimming spot.

activities.text: Snorkeling in the lagoon on the Cook's Bay side: butterflyfish, surgeonfish, and small rays glide above corals accessible from the beach. Mornings offer optimal visibility.

practical_info.tip: Mask and snorkel are enough, no need for fins

activities.text: Lagoon boat tour between the two bays. You sail at the foot of Mount Rotui, encountering stingrays and small blacktip reef sharks in the shallow waters around the motus.

visits.text: Te Fare Natura, Moorea's eco-museum, sits at the exit of Opunohu Bay. Interactive exhibits on reef ecosystems, endemic fauna, and the island's volcanic geology.
Take a detour to 'Magic Mountain' for a striking viewpoint over the turquoise lagoon on the west side. Access is via a short but steep track.
Temae Beach, in the northeast near the airport, ranks among the finest in French Polynesia. Immaculate white sand, transparent waters, and a direct view of Tahiti in the distance.
The Manutea fruit juice distillery, located in Opunohu Bay, processes pineapples and local fruits. Free tasting of artisanal juices, liqueurs, and jams.
Want a cultural show? Polynesian evenings on the island combine ma'a tahiti buffet, traditional dances, percussion, and fire performances under the stars.

activities.text: Three Coconuts Pass hike starting from the Opunohu Belvedere. The trail crosses dense tropical forest and emerges at a pass with views over both bays and the lagoon on the Haapiti side.
Polynesian cooking class: preparing poisson cru with lime and coconut milk, the emblematic dish of the fenua. Some guesthouses offer this workshop.

visits.text: The plane flies over Bora Bora's lagoon before landing on Motu Mute—the former airstrip built by the Americans in 1942. A boat shuttle runs to Vaitape, the island's main village.

Matira Beach, at the southern tip of the main island: a kilometer and a half of white sand fringed with coconut palms. It's Bora Bora's only public beach, and one of the most photographed in Polynesia. The water is shallow, the bottom sandy—ideal for swimming.
From Matira, Mount Otemanu (727 m) dominates the landscape. Its basalt summit is the symbol of Bora Bora—impossible to miss, it cuts against the sky from any point on the lagoon.
The small village of Vaitape stretches along the wharf. A few craft and black pearl shops line the main road. The atmosphere is calm, far from the bustle of the resorts on the motus.

activities.text: Lagoon boat tour: coral gardens, swimming with docile stingrays, and observing blacktip reef sharks in the shallows between the motus. Keep a respectful distance from wildlife.
Sunset from Matira Beach: the sky turns orange and pink while Mount Otemanu stands out in silhouette. Bring something for a picnic.

visits.text: Bora Bora still bears the marks of Operation Bobcat. In 1942, 4,000 GIs landed on this island of 1,000 inhabitants to turn it into a supply base in the Pacific. Eight 7-inch guns and anti-aircraft batteries were installed on the heights.

The Anau guns, at Pointe Fitiu, are the island's best-preserved. Double battery on reinforced concrete mounts, bunker, ammunition shelter, and network of trenches—all restored and explained by trilingual panels installed in 2021.

Continue around the island via Faanui Bay and its church at the foot of the mountain. Two more guns stand at Pointe Tereia, accessible by a short trail with views over the motus and overwater bungalows.
The Popoti Lookout, a former American radar post on the west coast, offers the best panoramic view of Bora Bora. Access via a steep 4WD track—on foot or by quad.
At Vaitape wharf, a commemorative plaque recalls the Seabees' presence (Navy construction battalions). At Motu Mute airport, a timeline chronicles the history of Operation Bobcat.

activities.text: Island tour by bike or scooter: the circular road runs about 32 km on flat terrain. You pass luxury hotels, fishing villages, and viewpoints over the lagoon.
Sunset outrigger canoe (va'a) trip. You glide across the lagoon while Otemanu glows red—book for the golden hour.

map_keywords: Passe sacrée Te Ava Mo'a Raiatea

visits.text: Uturoa, Raiatea's main town, stretches along a quiet waterfront. Its small covered market sells fish, tropical fruits, and local crafts. The atmosphere is much calmer than Papeete.

Marae Taputapuātea, inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage list since 2017, extends along the lagoon shore at Raiatea's southeastern tip. Dedicated to the god 'Oro, this political, ceremonial, and funerary center brought together chiefs from across the Polynesian triangle. Several marae with distinct functions succeed one another on a vast site of basalt stones facing the sacred pass Te Ava Mo'a.
Opposite the marae, the sacred mountain Tea'etapu dominates Opoa Valley. A trail leads to the summit for a plunging view over the site, lagoon, and ocean.

Raiatea is the cradle of Ma'ohi civilization: from this island, ancient Polynesian navigators set out to colonize Hawaii, New Zealand, and Easter Island. The Taputapuātea site remains a pilgrimage destination for Polynesians worldwide.

activities.text: Faaroa River ascent by boat or kayak—the only navigable river in French Polynesia. The motorized canoe pushes into a lush jungle of tree ferns, purau, and mape (Polynesian chestnuts). The guide tells valley legends.
Swimming and snorkeling at Motu Iriru or Ofetaro, two public islets in Raiatea's lagoon accessible by boat. White sand, crystal-clear water, and tropical fish.

map_keywords: Jardin de corail Tau Tau Taha'a

visits.text: Taha'a, nicknamed the Vanilla Island, shares the same lagoon as Raiatea—30 minutes by boat is enough to reach it. The island produces about 80% of all vanilla in French Polynesia, the Vanilla tahitensis variety prized by chefs worldwide.

Visit to a vanilla plantation: growers explain the manual pollination of flowers, harvesting, and the long months of preparation needed to obtain the fragrant brown pods. The sweet scent fills the greenhouse.
Stop at a family pearl farm to understand the grafting of Pinctada margaritifera oysters. Live demonstration and explanations on classifying Tahitian black pearls—luster, orient, shape, and size.
Taha'a's rum distillery produces organic agricole rum from sugarcane grown on former vanilla plots. Tasting available on-site.

activities.text: Drift snorkeling in the coral garden at Motu Tau Tau, northwest of Taha'a. You let the current carry you over a natural aquarium of colorful corals, anemones, and tropical fish. Shallow, accessible to everyone.

practical_info.tip: Protect yourself from the sun: the light bottom reflects UV rays

activities.text: Lunch on a deserted motu: Polynesian barbecue of grilled fish, cooked bananas, and coconut milk, your feet in the white sand facing the turquoise lagoon.
Observing blacktip reef sharks in the shallows on the reef side. They swim in very shallow water and pose no danger—still, keep a reasonable distance.

visits.text: Back in Tahiti, explore the west coast. Taharuu's black-sand beach in Papara (PK 39) unfurls a long wild strip battered by waves—a renowned local surf spot.
Marae Arahurahu, in Paea (PK 22.5 west coast), is Tahiti's best-restored. Its terraced stone platform, surrounded by coconut palms, still hosts reenactments of traditional ceremonies.
The Vaipahi water gardens (PK 49, Mataiea) offer a shaded botanical trail along waterfalls and pools amid dense tropical vegetation. Easy and free access.
The Maraa Grotto, carved in the coastal cliff at Paea, shelters crystal-clear freshwater pools in a fern-filled setting. A quick, surprising stop.
Stop at PK 18 beach (Punaauia), white sand this time, for a final easy snorkel on the coral heads with Moorea as backdrop.

activities.text: Back to the roulottes at Place Vaiete for one last evening of Tahitian street food: poisson cru, chao pao, steak frites, and Nutella crepes—all under the harbor lights.
Late-day stroll along Papeete's waterfront, from Bougainville Park to Place To'ata—the stage for Heiva i Tahiti, the major dance and song festival held every July.

map_keywords: Tombeau du Roi Pomare V Tahiti

visits.text: Last visit to Papeete market for monoi, vanilla, and pearl shopping. Vendors craft tiare crowns to take away—a Polynesian farewell symbol.
King Pomare V's tomb, in Arue on the east coast, houses the sepulcher of Tahiti's last king, who died in 1891. The white coral monument topped with a funeral urn overlooks the lagoon.
If time allows, push on to Mahina's pink Protestant temple, recognizable by its bright white and pink hues—one of Tahiti's most photogenic religious buildings.

activities.text: Optional hike to Fautaua Falls, accessible from Papeete. The river plunges nearly 300 meters in a cascade into a swimming pool. A permit is sometimes required—check conditions with the town hall.

practical_info.tip: Permit sometimes required, inquire the day before

activities.text: One last dip in the lagoon or at a west-coast beach before the transfer to Faa'a airport, located 5 km from Papeete.

seo.h1_title: Tahiti, Moorea & Bora Bora: Lagoons and Mountains
seo.intro_paragraph: From vibrant Papeete to sacred Raiatea, this 10-day itinerary island-hops across the Society Islands through four stopovers. Bustling markets and waterfalls in Tahiti, volcanic ridges and crystalline lagoons in Moorea, Bora Bora's infinite blue, then UNESCO heritage and vanilla in Raiatea—each island adds its own color to the journey.
seo.seo_hook: A complete French Polynesia island-hopping adventure: 4 islands, 10 days, where turquoise lagoons meet volcanic peaks and Ma'ohi culture

places_taglines.PF::papeete: Where roulottes sizzle at sunset and tiare crowns perfume the morning market
places_taglines.PF::paopao: Twin bays carved by ancient gods at the foot of sacred Mount Rotui
places_taglines.PF::vaitape: Gateway village to the South Pacific's most mesmerizing lagoon
places_taglines.PF::uturoa: Where Polynesian navigators once set sail to settle the Pacific triangle

itineraries.notes: Island-hopping across the Society Islands: markets and waterfalls on Tahiti, bays and ridges on Moorea, turquoise lagoon time on Bora Bora, and Polynesian heritage on Raiatea.
specialties: Poisson cru with lime and coconut milk
Monoi oil infused with tiare flowers
itineraries.subtitle: From Papeete to Raiatea, a journey through turquoise lagoons, eroded volcanoes, and sacred marae in the heart of the Polynesian triangle

highlights: Ferry Tahiti → Moorea: 30-min crossing with views over both bays
Flight Moorea → Bora Bora: lagoon flyover on landing approach
Flight Bora Bora → Raiatea: 20 min between the Leeward Islands
Flight Raiatea → Tahiti: 45-min return to the main island
